results.title: Time to fly
results.creator_credit: Liam O'Bree, Belle Willox and ACMI
results.brief_description: Belle Willox joined the WAAAFs because she always wanted to be a flyer like Amy Johnson. She joined when she was 18 and, though she never got to pilot a plane herself, there were certainly many ups and downs during her time in the war.
results.description: Belle Willox joined the WAAAFs because she always wanted to be a flyer like Amy Johnson. She joined when she was 18 and, though she never got to pilot a plane herself, there were certainly many ups and downs during her time in the war.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [St Arnaud Veterans]
results.brief_description: While many didn’t see active service, these ten veterans from St Arnaud count their time in the army as the most important part of their lives. Proud of their service, they tell of exciting adventures, adjusting to big changes and the friends they made along the way.
results.title_for_label: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [St Arnaud Veterans]

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2010]
results.brief_description: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.
results.title_for_label: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2010]
results.description: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.
description_for_label: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2009]
results.brief_description: 10 interviews with Victorian war veterans, created as part of the “In our words : Stories from Victorian veterans” Digital Storytelling workshop in August 2009, with the support of the Department of Planning and Community Development, the Shrine of Remembrance, and the Victorian Veterans Council.

results.title: An Interview with Stan Guilfoyle
results.brief_description: When he was 13, Stan Guilfoyle was in an accident in which he nearly died. From then on he believed in seizing every moment. This enthusiasm for life took him to the Royal Australian Air Force, where he became proficient at flying, using only the instruments in his cockpit to navigate. He tells of his time in Indonesia during World War II and passionately shares his views on war.
results.description: When he was 13, Stan Guilfoyle was in an accident in which he nearly died. From then on he believed in seizing every moment. This enthusiasm for life took him to the Royal Australian Air Force, where he became proficient at flying, using only the instruments in his cockpit to navigate. He tells of his time in Indonesia during World War II and passionately shares his views on war.

He tells of his time in Indonesia during World War II and passionately shares his views on war.

results.title: An Interview with Shirley Cornish
results.brief_description: Shirley Cornish joined the army when a friend, from the store where she worked, said she would. She joined the Australian Womens Army Service and spent most of her life in the service of the army, and tells of her times there and friends made. Army life often bled into Shirley’s personal life, losing a rank in order to spend more time with her mother and, later, joining the Bentleigh War Widows and Widowed Mothers after her husband died. Shirley considers joining this association to be the best thing she ever did and even went on to become its president.

results.title: An Interview with Raymond Jungwirth
results.brief_description: Raymond Jungwirth wanted to fly a spitfire but was convinced to undergo observer training. Initially trained in Canada, Raymond was posted to Europe, where he spent most of World War II. Here he provides a heartfelt account of friends made and lost, the waste of human life and visiting Belsen after the war and the lasting impression that stayed with him even after he returned to Australia.

results.title: An Interview with Major General Jim Hughes
results.brief_description: Major General Jim Hughes joined the army just after World War II. Army life suited him and he served as a platoon commander in Korea in the 1950s. He details one particularly long Sunday, during this time, when his company was ambushed by the Chinese and resulted in him maturing considerably in one day.

results.title: An Interview with Jim Dickson
results.brief_description: Commodore Jim Dickson came from a Naval family and joined the cadets at 13. As a ship navigator off the coast of Vietnam in 1965, he experienced the pressure of being responsible for the welfare of the crew and the ship. He reflects on the turbulence of the era, the bonds that are formed in times of adversity and the terrible waste wrought by war.
